text: hi I'm Alyssa Clark from the dining
section do you think you know everything
there is to know about bacon and eggs
did you know about bacon and egg pie
it's a specialty in New Zealand it's
kind of like a quiche except that
instead of mixing the eggs and bacon
together and making a custard you keep
them separate so that when you cut into
it you'd have nice big chunks of egg and
bacon what I've got here is a pre baked
9-inch pie crust homemade of course and
I'm just going to sprinkle the bottom
with some Canadian bacon and some
scallions the reason I'm using Canadian
bacon is that it's closer to the kind of
bacon they would use in New Zealand
which is much leaner than the bacon we
have here you could use regular American
bacon but you do have to fry it first so
it gets nice and crispy or you could
also just use cube pieces of ham I've
got six ounces of Canadian bacon here
and I'm gonna put half of it on the
bottom and then I'm gonna put the other
half on top
now I'm gonna carefully crack eight eggs
into the pie crust you don't want to
break the yolks by the way if you do
accidentally break a yolk just forge
ahead nobody will notice at the end once
your eggs are in you want to season them
really well with salt and pepper now I'm
gonna make a mixture of sriracha ketchup
and heavy cream and I'm gonna drizzle
that all over the eggs for the exact
recipe go to nytimes.com slash dining
kind of looks like Russian dressing but
with a punch it's not exactly drizzling
but as long as you get it
on top of the eggs you are in good shape
then just finish it off with some more
bacon and scallion then I'm going to
seal everything in with a top crust
I'm gonna roll this out a little thinner
than I would for a bottom crust
now you want to trim your dough so it
just fits over the top of the pie so
about 10 inches to get the top crust
nice and brown I'm gonna mix together
egg and a little bit of heavy cream and
brush it right on top
that's called an egg wash you just want
a thin layer of the egg wash you're not
gonna use all of it you want to slash
the top crust with a knife just so some
of the steam can escape but be careful
don't go deep because you don't want to
pierce a yolk now bake this at 400 until
the top is nice and shiny brown about 25
minutes so the top is golden brown the
center is just set when you cut into it
the eggs are gonna look hard-boiled with
bacon ketchup and sriracha those New
Zealanders know how to do bacon and eggs
you
